title: 107_hr1269
content: The "Global Health Act of 2001" may be cited as the official title of this Act. Key findings are outlined in Section 2. The "Global Health Act of 2001" finds that millions of childhood deaths in developing nations are caused by preventable diseases like pneumonia, diarrhea, malaria, and measles. Additionally, millions of women lack access to modern contraceptives, leading to pregnancy-related complications and deaths. According to the World Health Organization, 13 million people die annually from infectious diseases, with 6 diseases accounting for 90% of these deaths: pneumonia, diarrheal diseases, measles, tuberculosis, malaria, and HIV/AIDS. HIV/AIDS is the leading infectious disease threat globally, with 36.1 million people infected and over 15,000 new infections daily, including 6,000 cases in individuals aged 15-24. The text chunk "SEC. 3. ASSISTANCE TO IMPROVE GLOBAL HEALTH." summarizes the section on providing assistance to improve global health. The amendment emphasizes disease surveillance, prevention, and response to outbreaks to address global health threats. It also authorizes an increase in USAID assistance for fiscal year 2002 and subsequent years. For fiscal year 2002 and beyond, additional funds are authorized for global health programs, including child health, nutrition for pregnant women, family planning, HIV/AIDS prevention, and infectious disease control. $1 billion is allocated for these purposes. For fiscal year 2002 and beyond, $1 billion is authorized for global health programs. Allocation of funds includes $275 million for combating HIV/AIDS, $225 million for children's health, $200 million for infectious disease control, $200 million for family planning, and $100 million for the health and nutrition of pregnant women and mothers. Amounts appropriated remain available until expended. Coordination among federal departments and agencies is required. For effective utilization of funds under the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961, coordination among various federal departments and agencies is required, as stated by Congress. The term "HIV/AIDS" in this Act refers to infection with the human immunodeficiency virus, including acquired immune deficiency syndrome.
